TEAMING UP TO REMOVE PLASTIC WASTE FROM THE AUSTRALIAN OPEN  Australian enviro-tech startup, Samsara has teamed up with Tennis Australia to help reduce plastic waste at this yearÂ’s Australian Open (AO). The partnership sees Samsara collect tennis playersÂ’ discarded single-use plastic bottles and divert it to its Canberra recycling lab so it can be infinitely recycled.  Samsara launched last year on a mission to help end the plastic pollution crisis. Of the 2.5 million tonnes of plastic waste generated each year, only nine percent is sent for recycling while 84 percent ends up in landfills. The issue is current recycling methods are inefficient, time intensive and costly, and do not allow all plastic to be recycled (like coloured bottles) or recycled repeatedly without degradation.  Â Samsara has pioneered a new approach to infinitely recycle plastic. Using plastic-eating enzymes, SamsaraÂ’s technology breaks down plastic back to its core building blocks so it can be recreated into brand new plastic, again and again. The process is carbon-neutral, environmentally friendly and doesnÂ’t require any change to consumer behaviour. During the two-week Australian Open, Samsara is expected to collect approximately 5,000 single-use water bottles.  The partnership comes through Tennis AustraliaÂ’s venture arm, Wildcard Ventures, which has taken an investment position in Samsara. Wildcard Ventures joins existing founders including Woolworths Group, The Australian National University and deep tech venture fund, Main Sequence founded by CSIRO, who have joined forces to tackle the plastic waste problem with leading edge science.  As part of SamsaraÂ’s mission to address the plastic crisis, it is also gearing up to launch an education campaign aimed at helping Australians understand the plastic problem and potential solutions, via its sub brand, Sam. The ZEBRA (Zero wastE Blade ReseArch) consortium has produced the first prototype of its 100 per cent recyclable wind turbine blade!   Within the project, LM Wind Power, a GE Renewable Energy Business, has designed and built the worldâ€™s largest thermoplastic blade at its Ponferrada plant in Spain. This milestone is achieved after a year of material development and testing backed by sub-component level process trials by the consortium partners.   The 62-metre blade was made using Arkemaâ€™s Elium resin, which is a thermoplastic resin known for its recyclable properties together with the new high-performance Glass Fabrics from Owens Corning, LM Wind Power said.   Its purpose is to demonstrate the technical, economic, and environmental relevance of thermoplastic wind turbine blades on a full scale, with an eco-design approach to facilitate recycling.   The liquid thermoplastic resin is said to be perfectly adapted for the manufacturing of large parts by resin infusion, combined with Owens Corning high-performance fabrics. The resulting composite material is delivering similar performances to thermoset resins but with a key unique benefit: recyclability, LM Wind Power said.   Elium based composite components can be recycled using an advanced method called chemical recycling that enables to fully depolymerize the resin, separate the fiber from the resin and recover a new virgin resin & High Modulus Glass ready to be reused, closing the loop.   This method, developed by Arkema and CANOE partners, is tested on all composite parts including waste generated from production. Frustrated by wrong facts in media reports! This one happens too frequently and it misrepresents the scale of the plastics challenge and the actions required of us, industries and governments for a sustainable circular future.  Today, Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) news website published a long article on the impending final stage in the Federal Government's ban stopping the export of untreated waste plastic from Australia to other countries. The ban is for all plastics generated in Australia, and we consume/use over 3 million tonnes p/yr. Of this, around 40% is packaging, not 100%. 60% of our plastics are in every-day products like water pipe, garden furniture, rain water tanks, flooring, toys, fishing gear, car bumper bars, etc. This report by the ABC has drawn upon the facts and figures for packaging, like the 70% recycling targets for plastic packaging, and interviewed people connected with packaging, like CEO APCO, Brooke Donnelly.  The problem with this media report, as with so many others, is that the bans apply to all plastics, we have challenges with all plastics, and we need strategic measures that address all plastics. They are not to be blamed entirely, because in fact, Australia is yet to form strategies or targets for better design, recycling or circulation of the bulk of our plastics, the 60%. Australia has a packaging strategy, plenty of investments in grants, infrastructure, collections, training in packaging and plastic packaging, and almost nothing for plastics products. And yet plastic products are widespread, extensively used, with environmental impacts in terms of landfill, embodied energy and finite materials.  The consequence of such media mis-reporting, is that public and policy makers are misled in thinking that plastic packaging is all that matters, industry struggle to establish successful programs on durable plastic products and improve eco-design of plastic products, and we have record quantities of plastics going to landfills.  So I call on Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and all media outlets to be careful in presenting the full facts and enabling us to see the real scale of the plastics challenge and what we can and should do for more sustainable, circular plastics in Australia. https://lnkd.in/gm-KD_7C #recycling #packaging #plastics Simon Lockrey PhD, Richard Collins

Walking the tightrope of war.  In a democracy it is essential for decisions to be agreed by Parliament and the people. Although it appears slow and frustrating to those involved in active war this legal process must be concluded in order to bring a nation's wealth behind a campaign. Public opinion is a vital part of the democratic process.   Western leaders understand the fear and pain of Ukraine. They have the same fears. They don't want missiles hitting their own countries.  They want to do all they can to assist Ukraine (and themselves) for the long term future.  Our leaders are walking a tight rope of fear. If they fall to the left and do nothing they put off the day of reckoning for a while and hope the tyrant will stop and say 'that's enough'.   If they fall to the right and mount aggressive war they confront the possibility of escalating to an extreme level.  Somewhere in between is a balance between nothing and too much.   What that balance is depends on how close a nation is to the conflict and what they have to give up in order to fight.   Money, supplies, technology and weapons are already on the way but what about no fly zones or soldiers? Our leaders say 'Not yet, - not unless Putin extends his war outside of Ukraine.'  Intelligence is a weapon that can be supplied without risk. Where and what are the Russians weapons, what are their intentions? This intelligence allows the Ukrainians to use their arms efficiently.   It appears that the loose alliances of the west, the EU, NATO and the Australasians have agreed to try to contain the violence in Ukraine, - if possible, while doing all they can to help Ukraine win the battles.   The west is beating its drums on the borders with Ukraine and Russia to contain the conflict and to keep vital Russian defences fixed elsewhere. Air defences are patrolling no mans land in the sky, sending a message 'Don't come here. We will kill you!'. Putin is not as crazy as he would like us to think, he is staying on his own side of the fence.  Some are shouting for a total oil embargo to bankrupt Russia. Our leaders must consider whether this is more damaging to us than it is to Russia, (another tightrope). Such a decision could result in our own financial collapse. Without energy for industry our people would have to sacrifice their employment. In a democracy that would not work for long and support for Ukraine would wither. There is always a  fine balance for leaders to maintain.  Today they support Ukraine in Ukraine. They will do all they can to defeat Putin on the conventional battlefield. Dictators can't resign. If Putin fails he dies, his own people will finish him. He must not win!  Slava Ukraine!  Who Dares Shares!  Robin Horsfall

Earlier this week, I was celebrated as part of the new class of Partners, Principals and Managing Directors of Deloitte. Forgive the sentimentality that follows -- I rarely get personal on a professional forum, but an occasion like this warrants some mush!   I joined Deloitte 15 years ago right out of campus, joining what was then the AERS Innovation team based in India. Joining an innovation team in an offshore delivery center for what was then predominantly an audit support practice was by all accounts a non-traditional choice. However, whether it was ignorance or hubris that got me here, it has been an immensely rewarding and enriching experience.   I joined the firm completely green, having never had any professional experience. But in it I found a home. One where I was nurtured, encouraged, supported, and celebrated. Where skills I didnâ€™t know I had or didnâ€™t value much were carefully cultivated. Here I found mentors, sponsors, and champions; people who opened doors for me, and were always in my corner. A place that made room for my off-beat role and enabled me to flourish. I am filled with immense gratitude to those who have shaped this journey.  Deloitte also made room for changes to my life. Never have I felt like my opportunities were limited, or my potential undervalued because of choices I was making in my personal life. In fact, I attended my final interview for the MD promotion just a few weeks before I had my baby, I got the call letting me know I was promoted while I was on (a very generous) maternity leave, and I spent my first few months as MD away from work caring for a new child.
